children.name: Hence the value of theorems such as these:
keywords: Hence the value of theorems such as these:

children.name: Theorem. [Seese 1996] For every sentence φ of first-order logic and d ∈ {1, 2, ..}, the following problem can be solved in linear time: input: graph of degree d question: does it satisfy φ?
keywords: Theorem. [Seese 1996] For every sentence φ of first-order logic and d ∈ {1, 2, ..}, the following problem can be solved in linear time: input: graph of degree d question: does it satisfy φ?

children.name: Corollary. For every k and d, there is a linear time algorithm for dominating set of size k on graphs of degree at most d.
keywords: Corollary. For every k and d, there is a linear time algorithm for dominating set of size k on graphs of degree at most d.

children.name: Theorem. [Courcelle 1990] For every sentence φ of MSO and k ∈ {1, 2, ..}, the following problem can be solved in linear time: input: graph of treewidth k question: does it satisfy φ?
keywords: Theorem. [Courcelle 1990] For every sentence φ of MSO and k ∈ {1, 2, ..}, the following problem can be solved in linear time: input: graph of treewidth k question: does it satisfy φ?

children.name: Corollary. For every k, there is a linear time algorithm for Hamiltonian path on graphs of treewidth at most k.
keywords: Corollary. For every k, there is a linear time algorithm for Hamiltonian path on graphs of treewidth at most k.

children.name: Algorithmic meta-theorems
keywords: Algorithmic meta-theorems

children.name: Courcelle theorem
Follows immediately from these two results:
keywords: Follows immediately from these two results:

children.name: Theorem. [Bodlaender] For every k ∈ {1, 2, ...}, the following problem can be solved in linear time: input: a graph output: a tree decomposition of width k, or “no” if there is no such tree decomposition.
keywords: Theorem. [Bodlaender] For every k ∈ {1, 2, ...}, the following problem can be solved in linear time: input: a graph output: a tree decomposition of width k, or “no” if there is no such tree decomposition.

children.name: A hard algorithm.
keywords: A hard algorithm.

children.name: Robertson and Seymour give a simple cubic algorithm.
keywords: Robertson and Seymour give a simple cubic algorithm.

children.name: Lemma. For every k ∈ {1, 2, ...} and MSO sentence φ, the following problem can be solved in linear time: input: a tree decomposition of width k output: does the underlying graph satisfy φ?
keywords: Lemma. For every k ∈ {1, 2, ...} and MSO sentence φ, the following problem can be solved in linear time: input: a tree decomposition of width k output: does the underlying graph satisfy φ?

children.name: Tree automata
Theorem. Thatcher and Wright 1968] For finite trees, MSO and tree automata define the same languages.
keywords: Theorem. Thatcher and Wright 1968] For finite trees, MSO and tree automata define the same languages.

children.name: Fo on bounded degree
The main tool for this, and other similar results, is Gaifman’s theorem about the locality of first-order logic
keywords: The main tool for this, and other similar results, is Gaifman’s theorem about the locality of first-order logic

children.name: Gaifman
Theorem. [Gaifman 1982] Every sentence φ of first-order logic on graphs is equivalent to a Boolean combination of basic local sentences:
keywords: Theorem. [Gaifman 1982] Every sentence φ of first-order logic on graphs is equivalent to a Boolean combination of basic local sentences:

children.name: a basic local sentence
keywords: a basic local sentence

children.name: a number k ∈ {0, 1, ...}
keywords: a number k ∈ {0, 1, ...}

children.name: a number r ∈ {0, 1, ...} called the radius
keywords: a number r ∈ {0, 1, ...} called the radius

children.name: a first-order formula φ(x) which is r-local
keywords: a first-order formula φ(x) which is r-local

children.name: Local sentences
Group 2
keywords: Group 2

children.name: The r-neighbourhood of a vertex v in a graph is the vertices that can be reached from v using at most r edges
keywords: The r-neighbourhood of a vertex v in a graph is the vertices that can be reached from v using at most r edges

children.name: A formula φ(v) is r-local if it depends only on the r-neighbourhood of v:
keywords: A formula φ(v) is r-local if it depends only on the r-neighbourhood of v:

children.name: A syntactic characterization: all quantifiers are relativized to the r-neighbourhood of v.
keywords: A syntactic characterization: all quantifiers are relativized to the r-neighbourhood of v.
Local sentences

children.name: The theorem is effective, although with non-elementary complexity.
keywords: The theorem is effective, although with non-elementary complexity.
Gaifman

children.name: Proof.
keywords: Proof.

children.name: Bounded degree proof
Thanks to Gaifman’s theorem, it is enough to show that for every basic local sentence
keywords: Thanks to Gaifman’s theorem, it is enough to show that for every basic local sentence

children.name: For every vertex x, we can check φ(x) in constant time.
keywords: For every vertex x, we can check φ(x) in constant time.

children.name: Algorithm for k = 2.
keywords: Algorithm for k = 2.

children.name: For every vertex x₁, check if it satisfies φ(x₁)
keywords: For every vertex x₁, check if it satisfies φ(x₁)

children.name: After finding the first candidate for x₁, find some other x₂ which satisfies φ(x₂) and has distance > r from x₁
keywords: After finding the first candidate for x₁, find some other x₂ which satisfies φ(x₂) and has distance > r from x₁

children.name: This greedy algorithm can give a false negative.
keywords: This greedy algorithm can give a false negative.

children.name: vertex x₁ found by algorithm
keywords: vertex x₁ found by algorithm

children.name: vertices x₁ and x₂ needed to satisfy basic local sentence
keywords: vertices x₁ and x₂ needed to satisfy basic local sentence

children.name: The false negative can only happen if the basic local sentence is witnessed by a pair of vertices at distance ≤ 2r.
keywords: The false negative can only happen if the basic local sentence is witnessed by a pair of vertices at distance ≤ 2r.

children.name: Such pairs can be found in linear time.
keywords: Such pairs can be found in linear time.
Bounded degree proof

children.name: There are far-reaching generalizations of this result, beyond bounded degree.
keywords: There are far-reaching generalizations of this result, beyond bounded degree.

Consider a radius r ∈ {0, 1, ...} and two graphs:

children.name: We say that H is an r-minor of G if one can associate to each vertex of H a subset of vertices in G such that:
keywords: We say that H is an r-minor of G if one can associate to each vertex of H a subset of vertices in G such that:

children.name: Group 12
keywords: Group 12

children.name: 1. all subsets are pairwise disjoint and have radius at most r
keywords: 1. all subsets are pairwise disjoint and have radius at most r

children.name: 2. if two vertices in H are connected by an edge, then the same is true for the associated subsets in G
keywords: 2. if two vertices in H are connected by an edge, then the same is true for the associated subsets in G

children.name: Definition. [Nesetril and Ossona de Mendez 2011] A class of graphs C is nowhere dense if for every radius r ∈ {0, 1, ...}, not all graphs are r-minors of C.
keywords: Definition. [Nesetril and Ossona de Mendez 2011] A class of graphs C is nowhere dense if for every radius r ∈ {0, 1, ...}, not all graphs are r-minors of C.

children.name: examples of nowhere dense classes
Example 1. If C has bounded degree, then it is nowhere dense. An r-minor of a graph with degree at most d has degree at most dr +1
keywords: Example 1. If C has bounded degree, then it is nowhere dense. An r-minor of a graph with degree at most d has degree at most dr +1

children.name: Example 2. If C has bounded treewidth, then it is nowhere dense. An r-minor of a graph of treewidth k cannot be a (k+1)-clique
keywords: Example 2. If C has bounded treewidth, then it is nowhere dense. An r-minor of a graph of treewidth k cannot be a (k+1)-clique
examples of nowhere dense classes

children.name: twin-width definition
Consider a graph, with a partition of its vertices
keywords: Consider a graph, with a partition of its vertices

children.name: A
keywords: A

children.name: Two blocks are consistent if they are connected in the same way:
keywords: Two blocks are consistent if they are connected in the same way:

children.name: Blocks A and B are consistent, because ∀a ∈ A ∀b ∈ B edge(a, b)
keywords: Blocks A and B are consistent, because ∀a ∈ A ∀b ∈ B edge(a, b)

children.name: Blocks B and C are consistent, because ∀b ∈ B ∀c ∈ C ¬ edge(b, c)
keywords: Blocks B and C are consistent, because ∀b ∈ B ∀c ∈ C ¬ edge(b, c)

children.name: Blocks A and C are inconsistent
keywords: Blocks A and C are inconsistent

children.name: Definition [Bonnet, Kim, Thomassé, Watrigant 2020] A graph has twinwidth k ∈ {0, 1, 2, ...} if there is a sequence of partitions P1, ..., Pn on its vertices such that;
keywords: Definition [Bonnet, Kim, Thomassé, Watrigant 2020] A graph has twinwidth k ∈ {0, 1, 2, ...} if there is a sequence of partitions P1, ..., Pn on its vertices such that;

children.name: a) P1 has singleton blocks, Pn partition has one block
keywords: a) P1 has singleton blocks, Pn partition has one block

children.name: b) for every i ∈ {1, ..., n – 1}, Pi+1 is obtained from Pi by merging two blocks
keywords: b) for every i ∈ {1, ..., n – 1}, Pi+1 is obtained from Pi by merging two blocks

children.name: c) for every i ∈ {1, ..., n} and every block A ∈ Pi, at most k blocks of Pi are inconsistent with A.
keywords: c) for every i ∈ {1, ..., n} and every block A ∈ Pi, at most k blocks of Pi are inconsistent with A.

children.name: examples of twin-width
Example 1. Every clique has twinwidth 1.
keywords: Example 1. Every clique has twinwidth 1.
